Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of woman wearing a veil with a festival wreath (?) or other headdress. Her hair is in Isis braids, and possibly is a poor quality representation of Isis-Hathor. Head only. Mould-made and hollow with simple curved back. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core and abundant mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Published by Gutch (Gutch 1898-99, 81-2, no. 42) and dated to the late Hellenistic or early Roman period. Parallel dated c.300 BC parallel suggests this is an earlier form however (Bayer Niemeier 1988, no.9). Bayer Niemeier , E. 1988, Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann / Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik Frankfurt am Main I. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten, Melsungen.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 81-82, no. 42)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.439) (Phase 3)
